facts.text: Civil Appeal No. LXX of 1949 filed in Appellate Jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. LXX of 1949. Appeal from the judgment of the Allahabad High

facts.text: Appeal from judgment of Allahabad High Court by Verma and Yorke JJ dated 22nd April 1943.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment of the Allahabad High Court  Verma and Yorke JJ.  dated the 22nd April, 1943. C. Setalvad, Attorney-General for India  Sri Narain And- ley,

facts.text: Judgment of Civil Judge of Basti dated 6th November 1939 reversed by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Allahabad High Court dated April 22, 1943, which reversed on appeal those of the Civil Judge of Basti dated 6th of November 1939. The suit, out of which the

facts.text: Suit commenced by plaintiff (successor is present appellant) to recover Rs. 11,935 by enforcement of simple mortgage bond.

anchor.surface_text: The suit, out of which the appeal arises, was companymenced by the plaintiff, whose successor the present appellant is, to recover a sum of Rs. 11,935 by enforcement of a simple mortgage bond.

facts.text: Mortgage deed dated 8th March 1926 executed by Raja Pateshwari Partap Narain Singh in favour of Bhikhiram Sahu.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgage deed is dated the 8th of March 1926 and was executed by Raja Pateshwari Partap Narain Singh, the then holder of Basti Raj which is an impartible estate governed by the rule of primogeniture, in favour of Bhikhiram Sahu, the father of the original plaintiff Ramdeo,

facts.text: Basti Raj is an impartible estate governed by rule of primogeniture.

anchor.surface_text: Raja Pateshwari Partap Narain Singh, the then holder of Basti Raj which is an impartible estate governed by the rule of primogeniture, in favour of Bhikhiram Sahu,

facts.text: Loan of Rs. 5,500 advanced on hypothecation of immovable properties of the estate, interest 9% per annum, repayable within one year.

anchor.surface_text: to secure a loan of Rs. 5,500 advanced by the mortgagee on hypothecation of certain immovable properties appertaining to the estate of the mortgagor. The loan carried interest at the rate of 9 per cent per annum and there was a stipula- tion to pay the mortgage money within one year from the date of the bond.

facts.text: Mortgagor and mortgagee both dead at time of suit institution.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgagor and the mortgagee were both dead at the time when the suit was instituted, and the plaintiff in the action was Ramdeo Sahu, the son and heir of the mortgagee,

facts.text: Plaintiff Ramdeo Sahu, son and heir of mortgagee Bhikhiram Sahu.

anchor.surface_text: while the principal defendant was the eldest son of the mortgagor who succeeded to the Basti estate under the rule of primogeniture. It was stated in the plaint that absolutely numberhing was paid

facts.text: Principal defendant is eldest son of mortgagor, succeeded to Basti estate under primogeniture.

anchor.surface_text: the plaintiff in the action was Ramdeo Sahu, the son and heir of the mortgagee, while the principal defendant was the eldest son of the mortgagor who succeeded to the Basti estate under the rule of primogeniture.

facts.text: No payments made by mortgagor or successor towards mortgage dues.

anchor.surface_text: It was stated in the plaint that absolutely numberhing was paid by the mortgagor or his succes- sor towards the mortgage dues and the plaintiff claimed the principal amount of Rs. 5,500

facts.text: Defendant contended document not properly attested or validly registered, could not operate as mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: The substantial companytentions raised by the defendant were of a three-fold character. In the first place, it was urged that the document sued upon was number a properly attested or valid- ly registered document and companyld number operate as a mortgage instrument in law.

facts.text: Defendant contended no consideration for Rs. 2,000 (items 3 and 4).

anchor.surface_text: The second companytention raised was that there was numberconsideration in support of the transaction, at least to the extent of Rs. 2,000, which was represented by items 3 and 4 of the companysideration clause in the document.

facts.text: Defendant claimed relief under United Provinces Agriculturists Relief Act.

anchor.surface_text: The third and the last material defence related to a claim for relief under the United Provinces Agriculturists Relief Act. The trial Judge held in favour of the defendant on the last point

facts.text: Trial Judge decreed for plaintiff Rs. 5,500 principal with interest per UP Act, in installments.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge held in favour of the defendant on the last point mentioned above and negatived his other pleas. The result was that he made a preliminary decree for sale in favour of the plaintiff for recovery of the principal sum of Rs. 5,500 with interest at certain rates as are sanctioned by the U.P. Agriculturists Relief Act

facts.text: High Court reversed trial judge, dismissed suit holding bond not attested, suit beyond 6 years, no money decree.

anchor.surface_text: and agreeably to the provisions of that Act the decretal dues were directed to be paid in a number of instalments. Against this decision, the defendant took an appeal to the High Court of Allahabad which was heard by a Division Bench companysisting of Verma and York JJ. The learned Judges reversed the judgment of the trial Judge and dismissed the plaintiffs suit on one ground only, viz., that the bond was number attested

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on November 14, 1950 by MLKHERJEA J.

anchor.surface_text: L. Banerjee  H. J. Urnrigal, with him , for the respondents. 1950. November 14. The judgment of the Court was deliv- ered by. MLKHERJEA J.--This is an appeal against a judjment

facts.text: Harbhajan Lal and Jawala Prasad Tewari signed as attesting witnesses, Jawala Prasad Patwari as scribe.

anchor.surface_text: It will appear that the mortgage deed besides companytaining the signature of the executant, purports to bear the signatures of three other persons, two of whom are described as attesting wit- nesses and the third one as the scribe. Harbhajan Lal and Jawala Prasad Tewari purport to have signed the document as attesting witnesses and Jawala Prasad Patwari

facts.text: Jawala Prasad Tewari dead when suit brought.

anchor.surface_text: is the person who has signed it as the scribe. Jawala Prasad Tewari was admittedly dead when the suit was brought and Harbhajan Lal, the only surviving attesting witness was called

facts.text: Harbhajan Lal testified he signed as witness but neither he nor Tewari signed in presence of mortgagor, nor mortgagor in theirs; declared hostile.

anchor.surface_text: on behalf of the plaintiff to prove the execution of the deed as is required under section 68 of the Indian Evidence Act. Harbhajan Lal stated in the witness box that he did sign the document as a witness and so did Jawala Prasad Tewari, but neither of them signed it in the presence of the mortgagor number did the mortgagor sign in their presence.

facts.text: Harbhajan Lal signed at Collectorate Kutchery (Bar Library) brought by Bhikhi Ram, Ghur Lal, Jawala Prasad Patwari; mortgagor signature already there.

anchor.surface_text: On this statement being made, the witness was declared hostile and he was allowed to be cross examined by the plaintiffs Counsel. He was cross examined by the defendant also and in answer to the questions put to him by the defendants lawyer, he stated that he signed the deed at the Collector- ate Kutchery, meaning thereby the Bar Library, where he used to sit as a petition writer and the document was taken to him at that place by Bhikhi Ram Sahu, the mortgagee, Ghur Lal, a Karinda of the mortgagor, and Jawala Prasad Patwari, the scribe.

facts.text: Jawala Prasad Patwari testified draft prepared at Raja's sherista under instructions from Bhikhi Ram and Ghur Lal; taken to Kot for Raja signature; then to Collectorate for witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: The details of the defendants version relating to execution of this document were given by Jawala Prasad Patwari, who was the principal witness on the side of the defendatnt. He says that he prepared the draft at the sherista or the office of the Raja Sahib which is outside his Kot or palace. The draft was prepared under instructions from Bhikhi Ram, the mortgagee. and Ghur Lal, the Karinda of the mortgagor, both of whom were present when the draft was prepared.

facts.text: Plaintiff testified document executed and attested at one sitting in Raja's Kot on 8th March 1926; he, Harbhajan Lal, Buddhu Lal, Jawala Prasad Tewari present; draft by Buddhu Lal, scribed by Patwari at Raja's wish; Raja signed in presence of witnesses, they signed in presence of Raja.

anchor.surface_text: As against this, there is a companypletely different version given by the plaintiff himself and his witness Buddhu Lal. According to the plaintiff, the document was executed and attested at one and the same sitting in the Kot or palace of the Raja the terms had been settled beforehand between Bhikhi Ram and the mortgagor and on the 8th of November 1926 the plaintiff himself, and number his father, went to the Rajas palace

facts.text: Trial Court accepted plaintiff's version on attestation, rejected defendant's.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge was to decide which of the two versions was companyrect and he ac- cepted the story of the plaintiff and rejected that of the defendant.

facts.text: Supreme Court held High Court wrong to reverse trial court's finding on attestation; accepted trial court's finding.

anchor.surface_text: Applying this principle to the present case, we do number think that the High Court was justified in reversing the finding of the trial Judge on the question of attestiation of the document.

facts.text: Buddhu Lal was old servant of plaintiff's family, supported plaintiff's story.

anchor.surface_text: This story of the plaintiff is supported materially and on all points by Buddhu Lal, who was an old servant of the family, though he was numberlonger in service when he deposed in companyrt.

facts.text: Harbhajan Lal was professional deed writer employed by plaintiff's father.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the evidence on the record that Harbhajan Lal, who was a pro- fessional deed writer, was usually employed for writing deeds of the plaintiffs father

facts.text: Signatures of executant and Harbhajan Lal in same ink.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge relied to some extent upon the fact that the signatures of the executant and Harbhajan Lal were in the same ink in support of his companyclusion

section 68 of the Indian Evidence Act. Harbhajan Lal stated in the witness box that he did sign the document as a witness and so did Jawala Prasad Tewari, but neither of them signed it in the presence of the mortgagor nor did the mortgagor sign in their presence.

anchor.surface_text: The rule is--and it is nothing more than a rule of practice --that when there is conflict of oral evidence of the parties on any matter in issue and the decision hinges upon the credibility of the witnesses, then unless there is some special feature about the evidence of a particular witness which has escaped the trial Judges notice or there is a sufficient balance of improbability to displace his opinion as to where the credibility lies, the appellate court should not interfere with the finding of the trial Judge on a question of fact.

concepts.interpretation: Appellate court should not reverse trial court's finding on oral evidence credibility unless special reasons or inherent improbabilities; trial judge's view entitled to great weight as saw witnesses.

issues.text: Whether the document sued upon was a properly attested or validly registered document and could operate as a mortgage instrument in law

anchor.surface_text: the document sued upon was not a properly attested or validly registered document and could not operate as a mortgage instrument in law.

issues.text: Whether there was no consideration in support of the transaction, at least to the extent of Rs. 2,000 represented by items 3 and 4 of the consideration clause

anchor.surface_text: The second contention raised was that there was no consideration in support of the transaction, at least to the extent of Rs. 2,000, which was represented by items 3 and 4 of the consideration clause in the document.

issues.text: Whether the High Court had justification for reversing the trial court's finding on the question of attestation

anchor.surface_text: the main contention raised by the learned Attorney-General, who appeared in support of the appeal, is that in arriving at its decision on the question of attestation, the High Court approached the matter from a wrong standpoint altogether and on the materials in the record it had no justification for reversing the findings of the trial court on that point.

anchor.surface_text: the suit was instituted beyond 6 years from the date of the bond, no money decree could be claimed by the plaintiff.

issues.text: Whether the appellate court should interfere with the trial Judge's finding of fact on conflicting oral evidence hinging on witness credibility

anchor.surface_text: The rule is--and it is nothing more than a rule of practice --that when there is conflict of oral evidence of the parties on any matter in issue and the decision hinges upon the credibility of the witnesses, then unless there is some special feature about the evidence of a particular witness which has escaped the trial Judges notice or there is a sufficient balance of improbability to displace his opinion as to where the credibility lies, the appellate court should not interfere with the finding of the trial Judge on a question of fact.

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, it was urged that the document sued upon was not a properly attested or validly registered document and could not operate as a mortgage instrument in law.

arguments.court_reasoning: Trial court's finding on proper attestation upheld; High Court reversal unjustified as evidence supports plaintiff's version and appellate interference unwarranted

anchor.surface_text: The second contention raised was that there was no consideration in support of the transaction, at least to the extent of Rs. 2,000, which was represented by items 3 and 4 of the consideration clause in the document.

arguments.court_reasoning: Trial court granted relief with scaled interest and installments; not disturbed by Supreme Court

arguments.claim: The bond was not attested in the manner required by law and consequently could not rank as a mortgage bond and as the suit was instituted beyond 6 years from the date of the bond, no money decree could be claimed by the plaintiff

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges reversed the judgment of the trial Judge and dismissed the plaintiffs suit on one ground only, viz., that the bond was not attested in the manner required by law and consequently could not rank as a mortgage bond and as the suit was instituted beyond 6 years from the date of the bond, no money decree could be claimed by the plaintiff.

arguments.court_reasoning: Reversal of trial court's attestation finding unjustified; appellate court cannot interfere without special reasons or improbabilities

arguments.claim: In arriving at its decision on the question of attestation, the High Court approached the matter from a wrong standpoint altogether and on the materials in the record it had no justification for reversing the findings of the trial court on that point

anchor.surface_text: It is against this judgment that the plaintiff has come up on appeal to this Court, and the main contention raised by the learned Attorney-General, who appeared in support of the appeal, is that in arriving at its decision on the question of attestation, the High Court approached the matter from a wrong standpoint altogether and on the materials in the record it had no justification for reversing the findings of the trial court on that point.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court's approach improper; trial finding consistent with evidence and probabilities

arguments.claim: When there is conflict of oral evidence of the parties on any matter in issue and the decision hinges upon the credibility of the witnesses, then unless there is some special feature about the evidence of a particular witness which has escaped the trial Judge's notice or there is a sufficient balance of improbability to displace his opinion as to where the credibility lies, the appellate court should not interfere with the finding of the trial Judge on a question of fact

anchor.surface_text: The rule is--and it is nothing more than a rule of practice --that when there is conflict of oral evidence of the parties on any matter in issue and the decision hinges upon the credibility of the witnesses, then unless there is some special feature about the evidence of a particular witness which has escaped the trial Judges notice or there is a sufficient balance of improbability to displace his opinion as to where the credibility lies, the appellate court should not interfere with the finding of the trial Judge on a question of fact.

arguments.claim: If the evidence as a whole can reasonably be regarded as justifying the conclusion arrived at at the trial, and especially if that conclusion has been arrived at on conflicting testimony by a tribunal which saw and heard the witnesses, the appellate court will bear in mind that it has not enjoyed this opportunity and that the view of the trial Judge as to where credibility lies is entitled to great weight

anchor.surface_text: But if the evidence as a whole can reasonably be regarded as justifying the conclusion arrived at at the trial, and especially if that conclusion has been arrived at on conflicting testimony by a tribunal which saw and heard the witnesses, the appellate court will bear in mind that it has not enjoyed this opportunity and that the view of the trial Judge as to where credibility lies is entitled to great weight.

arguments.claim: The rule that appellate court should be slow to differ from trial Judge did not apply as the trial Judge did not base conclusions on impressions from demeanour of witnesses but upon inherent improbability of defendant's witnesses' circumstances

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court in dealing with the appeal do observe, at the beginning of their discussions, that on a question of fact the appellate court should be slow to differ from the conclusions arrived at by the trial Judge who had seen and heard the witnesses but in their opinion, this rule did not apply to the present case as the trial Judge here did not base his conclusions on the impres- sions created in his mind by the witnesses who deposed before him.

arguments.court_reasoning: It would not detract from value of trial Judge's finding if not expressly based on demeanour; duty is to see if evidence as whole justifies conclusion

arguments.claim: The trial Judge's reasons for finding defendant's case unreliable were inconclusive and unsound; plaintiff's story improbable and not worthy of belief

anchor.surface_text: What the trial Judge relied upon, it is said, was not the demeanour of the witnesses as index of their credibility but upon the inherent improbability of the circumstances deposed to by the defendants witnesses. ... The learned Judges of the High Court then proceed to examine and discuss at great length the different reasons put forward by the trial Judge in support of his finding that the defendants case was unreliable. These reasons are held to be inconclusive and unsound and the High Court further found that the plaintiffs story as narrated by him and his servant is improbable and not worthy of belief.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court's approach improper; trial finding supported by circumstances and probabilities

arguments.claim: Plaintiff's presence (not father) at Raja's palace for execution improbable as against Indian customs and indecorous for borrower of high social position

anchor.surface_text: In the opinion of the High Court the story narrated by the plaintiff and his servant is untrue, and the main reason given is that it is not at all probable that the plaintiff and not his father Bhikhi Ram was present at the palace of the Raja when the document was executed. The mortgagor, it is said, was an influential person in the locality occupying a very high social position and it would be indecorous and against Indian customs for a man like Bhikhi Ram not to be personally present when the Raja was going to execute a document in his favour.

arguments.court_reasoning: Raja was borrower, terms settled beforehand, adult son experienced in business could represent; not first borrowing

arguments.claim: New story manufactured by plaintiff to prove attestation after Harbhajan Lal turned hostile

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges seem to think that the plaintiff was not really at the spot when the mortgage deed was executed and as Bhikhi Ram was dead, this story was manufactured by the plaintiff in order to ... Mr. Banerjee appearing for the defendant respondent went to the length of suggesting that it was only after Harbhajan Lal turned hostile in the witness box and denied that he attested the document that the new story was invented by the plaintiff.

arguments.court_reasoning: Plaintiff deposed immediately after Harbhajan Lal; argument on flimsy basis

arguments.claim: Presence of Harbhajan Lal and Buddhu Lal at execution improbable
arguments.court_reasoning: Harbhajan professional deed writer usually employed by plaintiff's father; Buddhu old trusted servant; natural presence

arguments.claim: In mofussil districts, Patwari generally employed for scribing deeds, so improbable Harbhajan intended as scribe
arguments.court_reasoning: Harbhajan scribed many for plaintiff's father; would have if Patwari not present; deference to Raja's wish

arguments.claim: Signatures in same ink not reliable test; Harbhajan signed later; many know law but don't comply due to carelessness
arguments.court_reasoning: Harbhajan experienced deed writer knew attestation requirements; inconceivable he attested improperly; signed at execution

arguments.claim: Trial court's finding on attestation supported by demeanour, improbabilities in defence, same ink, etc.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge was to decide which of the two versions was correct and he accepted the story of the plaintiff and rejected that of the defendant.

arguments.court_reasoning: Evidence as whole justifies conclusion; no element of improbability outweighing finding

arguments.claim: Harbhajan Lal stands condemned by his own statement; knew attestation meaning and signed properly at Raja's Kot
Jawala Prasad Patwari under control of defendant and cannot be trusted

holdings.text: The High Court was not justified in reversing the finding of the trial Judge on the question of attestation of the document.

anchor.surface_text: Applying this principle to the present case, we do number think that the High Court was justified in reversing the finding of the trial Judge on the question of attestiation of the document.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied rule of appellate practice on not interfering with trial court's credibility findings absent special features or improbabilities; evidence as whole supports trial finding.

holdings.text: The finding of the trial Judge on the question of attestation is perfectly consistent with the circumstances and probabilities of the case.

anchor.surface_text: Our companyclusion is that the finding of the trial Judge on the question of attestation is perfectly companysistent with the circumstances and probabilities of the case and the learned Judge did number omit anything which ought to have been present to his mind in companying to a companyclusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial judge's acceptance of plaintiff's version supported by witness evidence, probabilities, same ink, witness backgrounds; rejected defense improbabilities as inadequate.

holdings.text: Harbhajan Lal knew perfectly well what attestation means in law and he did sign the document as an attesting witness at the Rajas Kot after the document was executed.

anchor.surface_text: Whatever that may be, we have numberhesitation in holding that Harbhajan Lal knew perfectly well what attestation means in law and he did sign the document as an attesting witness at the Rajas Kot after the document was executed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harbhajan experienced deed writer aware of requirements; his conduct and evidence inconsistent with improper attestation; same ink and circumstances support.

holdings.text: The evidence on the record taken as a whole fully supports the finding [of proper attestation], and the High Court has reversed it on totally inadequate grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence on the record taken as a whole fully supports the finding, and in our opinion the High Court has reversed it on totally inade- quate grounds.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Followed precedents (Watt v. Thomas); no special features escaped trial notice; no sufficient improbabilities; appellate duty to assess if evidence justifies trial conclusion.

holdings.text: Jawala Prasad Patwari is apparently a man under the control of the defendant and cannot be trusted.

anchor.surface_text: Jawala Prasad Patwari is apparently a man under the companytrol of the defendant and cannot be trusted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Witness aligned with defendant; court discounts his testimony in favor of overall evidence.

holdings.text: When there is conflict of oral evidence... the appellate court should not interfere with the finding of the trial Judge on a question of fact unless there is some special feature... or sufficient balance of improbability.

anchor.surface_text: The rule is--and it is numberhing more than a rule of practice --that when there is companyflict of oral evidence of the parties on any matter in issue and the decision hinges upon the credibility of the witnesses, then unless there is some special feature about the evidence of a par- ticular witness which has escaped the trial Judges numberice or there is a sufficient balance of improbability to dis- place his opinion as to where the credibility lies, the appellate companyrt should number interfere with the finding of the trial Judge on a question of fact.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restated and applied established rule of practice from precedents like Watt v. Thomas.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court judgment and decree set aside; trial court's finding on attestation upheld, restoring preliminary decree for sale in favour of plaintiff

edges.explanation: Argument a1 on lack of proper attestation and document not operating as mortgage addresses the issue of limitation bar if not a mortgage due to attestation.
Argument a11 on flimsy basis for attestation supports argument a1 on improper attestation and invalid mortgage.
Argument a11 undermining attestation proof supports argument a4 on bond not being mortgage due to lack of attestation.
Argument a11 on manufactured story to prove attestation addresses the issue's premise of lack of attestation leading to 6-year limitation.
Argument on improbable presence of Harbhajan Lal and Buddhu Lal rebuts satisfaction of presence requirement in attestation
Improbable presence argument rebuts holding that reversal unjustified
a14 counters a12's improbability claim by noting later signing, ink unreliability, and knowledge despite carelessness
Argument that Harbhajan knew requirements and signed claims to satisfy attestation despite later signing
Argument on Harbhajan compliance despite carelessness supports no justification for reversal
Argument on Harbhajan knowing requirements and signing supports holding that he signed as attesting witness
The argument of entitlement claims that the conditions of the Act for scaled interest and installments are satisfied.
The argument that defendant is entitled to relief under the Act directly addresses the issue of entitlement.
